plausible_answers.text: pure potentiality that is actualized through education

qas.question: What did Al Farabi say tabula rasa was?
What did Aristotle call the active intellect?

context: During the Middle Ages <a0_0>Aristotle<a0_0/>'s theory of tabula rasa was developed by <a1_0><b5_0>Islamic<b5_0/><a1_0/> philosophers starting with Al Farabi, developing into an elaborate theory by Avicenna and demonstrated as a thought experiment by Ibn Tufail. For <b7_0>Avicenna<b7_0/> (Ibn Sina), for example, the tabula rasa is a <b6_0>pure potentiality that is actualized through education<b6_0/>, and knowledge is attained through "empirical familiarity with objects in this world from which one abstracts universal concepts" developed through a "syllogistic method of reasoning in which observations lead to propositional statements which when compounded lead to further abstract concepts". The intellect itself develops from a <a2_0><b9_0>material intellect<b9_0/><a2_0/> (al-'aql al-hayulani), which is a potentiality "that can acquire knowledge to the <a3_0>active intellect<a3_0/> (<b8_0>al-'aql al-fa'il<b8_0/>), the state of the human intellect in conjunction with the perfect source of knowledge". So <a4_0>the immaterial "active intellect"<a4_0/>, separate from any individual person, is still essential for understanding to occur.
